awd_titl_txt: Study of evaporation, micro-explosion, and combustion of nanofluid fuel droplets
awd_abstract_narration:
Many industrial applications involve evaporating liquid containing small-size particles. One example is to manufacture pharmaceutical powder aggregates in a way that they would be easily inhaled or ingested. In this application, the shape and density of aggregates determine the easiness with which the patient take the medication. Burning fuels containing particles, such as heavy fuel oils or rocket propellants, also involves similar evaporation process. In the case of burning fuels, the shape and density of the particle aggregates also affect the means and effectiveness with which particles are captured to minimize pollutant emissions. In this project, effects of particle size and concentration on liquid evaporation and burning will be characterized. The effort will be mainly experimental, aided by theoretical analysis for a full understanding of the evaporation, burning, and aggregate formation mechanisms. Both undergraduate and graduate students with diverse backgrounds will be recruited and involved in this project.

The proposed study uses the combination of the electrospray technique to generate fuel droplets containing nano-size energetic particles, which are freely suspended in space by the electro-dynamic balance. The droplet will then be ignited for combustion study, and the results will be compared with those without adding nano particles. The proposed study will answer the following specific questions: (1) Does the droplet burning follow the conventional d-square law due to the presence of particles and why? (2) Can the existing theory explain the non-d-square behavior? (3) How does the droplet burn when the droplet is electrically charged? (4) Is there secondary atomization during the single-droplet evaporation due to the Rayleigh charge limit (the critical charge density of a droplet)? (5) How does the aluminum particle affect the secondary atomization, Rayleigh limit, ignition, and burning? The proposed study is of great significance in advancing the power density of energy systems. This work has the main application in propulsion as adding metal energetic particles to liquid propellants can increase both the gravimetric and volumetric energy density of the propellant, thus increasing the range of the atmospheric flights and space vehicles. In addition to combustion, this work is also relevant to the dynamics of functional droplets, sprays, and heat/mass transfer. The results also have implications for other applications, such as food, pharmaceutical, ceramic, chemical, and nanotechnology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Nanofluids have received significant attention due to their enhanced energy content and thermo-physical properties compared to pure fluids. In many applications, the nanoparticles in a vaporizing droplet must be transported to the surface to exploit their properties. In combustion of nanofluid fuels containing metallic nanoparticles, the highly energetic nanomaterials need to be transported to the surface of the droplet where they can reach the reacting zone. In the field of pharmaceutics, in the delivery of inhalable medication, parameters such as droplet size, surface drug concentration, and shell porosity for the time-release of medication must be carefully engineered.

 

The current investigation intends to elucidate the phenomena of particle mobility and inclusion onto the droplet surface to the point of formation of a compact shell of particles in non-reactive and reactive scenarios. The experimental methodology uses an electrodynamic balance (EDB) to capture and freely suspend droplets during evaporation. The droplets generated with electrospray contain electrical charges, which then are susceptible to the electric fields from EDB electrodes. The non-evaporating electrical charges, allow us to investigate additional phenomena on evaporating droplets: Coulombic fission which occur when repulsive electrical forces overcome the surface tension.

 

High speed imagery are acquired and used to evaluate the droplet size and morphology over the evaporative/burning lifetime, as well as to characterize the effects of Coulombic fissions on the droplets and drying shells of particles. Instantaneous droplet diameter is used to calculate the droplet charge, mean and surface particle concentration, and the evaporative behavior. The experimental data is used to validate theoretical models which suggest that as particles are deposited on the receding surface of the vaporizing droplet, they partially block the effective area for gasification, and thus the evaporation/combustion rate is decreased until particles entirely occupy the surface, reaching a terminal shell size. Time to shell formation, and shell diameter depend on the relative motion of particles within the droplet given by Peclet number (), which is a function of experimental parameters such as vaporization rate, particle size and liquid viscosity.

 

Evaporation of nanofluid droplets yielded the instantaneous droplet diameter, evaporation rate constant, and the evaporation behavior in terms of conformity to- or deviation from the linear d2 law. Photographs of dry shells are presented for the various liquid-nanoparticle combinations and initial concentrations evaluated. Shell size and morphology are of interest. As the spherical droplet dries, the shell may retain its shape or be deformed, either by collapse of its crest, or by a permanent deformation resulting from a late Coulombic fission.

 

Evaporation of charged droplets of volatile liquids, namely short-chained alcohols over a broad range of ambient relative humidity (12 < RH < 70%) produced novel results related to the hygroscopy of these materials as they condense and absorb water from the surroundings. Photographs evidence the addition of water onto the evaporating droplet, and a subsequent liquid-liquid phase separation of alcohol and water that results from the non-ideal mixing dynamics of the two species. A secondary effect of water intake into the droplet is the complete cease of evaporation, where the droplet reaches a terminal, constant diameter which can be held in the EDB for several hours, while the evaporative lifetime of the droplet is in the order of one minute. The droplet is then assumed to reach thermal and phase equilibria with the gas phase. This can be explained by the combined effect of charges on dipolar molecules in the gas phase and the reduction of vapor pressures of alcohol and water within the droplet predicted by Raoult’s law.

 

Lastly, experimental work on the combustion of pure and nanofluid droplets doped with non-reactive (aluminum oxide) and reactive (metallic aluminum) nanoparticle materials has yielded data on the burning rate, flame structure, particle expulsion and ignition due to microexplosions, and shell formation. These phenomena are presented as a function of initial particle concentration. Ignition of metallic aluminum nanoparticles was observed during the second half of the droplet burning lifetime.

 

The findings from this study are expected to shed light on the coupled effects of electric charges, nanoparticle concentration, Peclet number and particle reactivity on nanofluid droplet vaporization. Mechanisms of secondary atomization, namely Coulombic fissions and microexplosions can be advantageous in the production of microdroplets much smaller than the mother droplet. This can find applications in fine inkjet printing and electrospray painting, localized drug delivery, and reduced soot and NOx in combustion engines. This study has also found promising results in our experiments concerning the hygroscopy and cease of evaporation in volatile alcohols, which can be utilized toward more controlled distillation processes, water de-contamination techniques, as well as meteorological applications such as cloud formation and rain induction.


Last Modified: 09/08/2022
Modified by: Ruey-Hung Chen
